statement.p:
On the graph below, draw:
The tangent line to y=f(x) at P,
the tangent line to y=f(x) at Q, and
the secant line to y=f(x) through P and Q.

solution.p: The tangent line to y=f(x) at a point should go through the point, and be in the same direction as f at that point. The secant line through P and Q is simply the straight line passing through P and Q.

statement.p:
Suppose a curve y=f(x) has tangent line y=2x+3 at the point x=2.
True or False: f(2)=7
True or False: f(3)=9

hint.p: The tangent line to a curve at point P passes through P.

ol.label: a
ol.li: In general, this is false. For most functions f(x) this will be false, but there are some functions for which it is true.

ol.label: a
ol.li: True: since y=2x+3 is the tangent line to y=f(x) at the point x=2, this means the function and the tangent line have the same value at x=2. So f(2)=2(2)+3=7.

In general, this is false. We are only guaranteed that the curve y=f(x) and its tangent line y=2x+3 agree at x=2. The functions f(x) and 2x+3 may or may not take the same values when x\ne 2. For example, if f(x)=2x+3, then of course f(x) and 2x+3 agree for all values of x. But if f(x) = 2x+3 +(x-2)^2, then f(x) and 2x+3 agree only for x=2.

statement.p: Let L be the tangent line to a curve y=f(x) at some point P. How many times will L intersect the curve y=f(x)?

hint.p: Try drawing tangent lines to the following curves, at the given points P:

solution.p: Since the tangent line to the curve at point P passes through point P, the curve and the tangent line touch at point P. So, they must intersect at least once. By drawing various examples, we can see that different curves may touch their tangent lines exactly once, exactly twice, exactly three times, etc.
